issue.title: Implement MultivariateNormal distribution
issue.body:
This also slightly simplifies `Normal` logic to match `MultivariateNormal` logic.

This eagerly converts to a precision matrix. We'll probably want to refactor this to use GPyTorch's LazyTensor at some point #48 .

This does not implement recognition of affine transforms #72, and has only very simple conversions to `Gaussian`.

## Tested

- added test of density
- added test of conversion to `Gaussian`

issue.title: Support for pattern matching with the unification library
issue.body:
I was looking into options for pattern matching and came across the [`unification`](https://github.com/mrocklin/unification/) library, and it turns out it's super easy to add support for Funsor expressions thanks to the magic of `multipledispatch`.  We should be able to use this as a substrate to implement #72.

Tasks:
- [x] Add a couple tests

issue.title: Implement a linearize interpretation
issue.body:
~~Blocked by #72~~

One approach to implementing Extended Kalman Filter-like updates is to linearize transformations. A motivating example is sensor fusion #85 .

## Related work
- https://arxiv.org/pdf/1903.09136.pdf

issue.title: Add an Affine term to represent multilinear functions of real Variables
issue.body:
Pair coded with @fritzo.  Addresses #72.

This PR adds an `Affine` term for representing multilinear functions of `Variable`s and includes it in the `eager` interpretation by default.

Tasks:
- [x] Implement `eager_subs`
- [x] Fix tests that were broken by changes to `eager`

issue.title: Add rule for creating Gaussians from Affine inputs
issue.body:
Addresses #72.  Pair coded with @fritzo.

This PR updates the `eager` pattern for `Normal` to allow constructing `Gaussian` terms from `Affine` inputs.  Currently only supports scalar real variable inputs.  The Kalman filter example has also been updated to demonstrate the new functionality.

issue.title: Promote Einsum to a funsor for pattern matching
issue.body:
Addresses #72

This promotes the `torch_einsum()` function to an `Einsum` funsor so we can add patterns that match against it. This also refactors the `torch_tensordot()` function to use `Einsum`.

Note I've added einsum string validation to the `Einsum` class, so that we can detect errors before patterns are matched; previously errors would only be detected at function evaluation time.

## Tested
- refactoring is exercised by existing tests

issue.title: Add a single normal form for sum-product contractions

milestone.title: Initial release
milestone.description: Working implementations of the examples in the design doc as well as any necessary infrastructure

issue.body:
Resolves #156 

As outlined in #156 I'm using this as a staging branch for the refactoring PRs associated with the proposed changes there:
- [x] #157 Original PR ([diff](https://github.com/pyro-ppl/funsor/pull/157/files/6fa04c681c39630fb2edaf8099ce3e23f3c71856))
- [x] #173 Refactor Affine into Contraction (https://github.com/pyro-ppl/funsor/pull/157/commits/e20978978283998341f5ed75a755cebc76fa2bab)
- [x] #165 Refactor optimizer to use Contraction and normalize (https://github.com/pyro-ppl/funsor/pull/157/commits/a4b2ec29b10f6649d86cf9fee24d56e574b279c8)
- [x] #169 Refactor Joint into multivariate Delta and Contraction (https://github.com/pyro-ppl/funsor/pull/157/commits/d2c79b0c8cdab99b370ca160de53dc8d62469dd9)
- [x] Separate unfolding from normalization (https://github.com/pyro-ppl/funsor/pull/157/commits/ffdd38176567242fde59ab1f070488ab98cce72e)
- [x] Troubleshoot performance issues (mostly caused by repeated unfolding)
- [x] Use #212 for pattern matching
- [x] Remove obsolete patterns ([diff](https://github.com/pyro-ppl/funsor/pull/157/files/8714349a6fb18cde2b8c04e96b0c289c8187015f..e59d85fa5a0db52e478827141eec95ada4a52645))
- [x] Update `MultiDelta` to keep separate `log_density`s for each `point` (https://github.com/pyro-ppl/funsor/pull/157/commits/30cbcb1c13806991cdeb70e5618799b60cf844b9)
- [x] Fix regressions in `adjoint` and `einsum`
- [x] Add missing patterns for `minipyro`
- [x] Update bound inference tests for `Number`

Original description:
This PR takes a first step towards the goals in #156 by adding two things:
1. A `Contraction` term representing finitary sum-product operations that takes advantage of `multipledispatch.Variadic` for pattern matching.  This is also necessary for #72.
2. A `normalize` interpretation that uses associative and distributive properties to put linear expressions into something like DNF, grouping operations into single `Contraction` terms where possible.

As a demonstration, I have included patterns and tests illustrating how `Joint` is equivalent to interleaving `eager` and `normalize`.

Tested:
- I copied smoke tests and test cases verbatim from `test_joint.py`, `test_gaussian.py`, `test_affine.py` and `test_einsum.py`

issue.title: Refactor Affine into Contraction
issue.body:
Part of the refactoring outlined in #156.  This PR removes the `Affine` term and replaces it with the `Contraction` normal form.  I've added a property `is_affine` to `Contraction` which says whether a given `Contraction` is multiaffine in its real input variables.  Should mostly address #72 

Tested:
- Previous `Affine` tests all still pass

issue.title: Add passing+failing tests for biased filtering
issue.body:
Addresses #72 
Based on #221 
Pair coded with @jpchen 

This adds two tests (one passing, one failing) for `sequential_sum_product()` with global bias terms. The failing test involves a pattern `Gaussian(x=y[z])`, where we currently cannot recognize `y[z]` as a linear function of `y`.

I'm adding this now because it is somewhat blocking @jpchen and I'd like to track progress.

issue.title: FR add patterns for substituting Affine into Gaussian
issue.body:
Blocked by #157 (so as not to proliferate deprecated `Affine` patterns)

This came up in @jpchen's biased kalman filter experiment, where we are using `matrix_and_mvn_to_funsor()` to create a `Joint`, then substituting `data + bias` into this distribution. Currently `Affine` patterns exist for `dist.Normal` funsors, but not raw `Gaussian`s.

body: Thanks for keeping tracks of those tasks! It is convenient for me to understand what is going on.

issue.title: bias estimation experiment
issue.body:
paircoded with @fritzo 

~~Blocked by #72~~

This adds an example using exact Gaussian sensor fusion to estimate sensor bias in a multi-sensor single-object tracking problem. Right now the numbers in the paper is using random acceleration model.  It also is doing manual sequential sum product rather than GaussianHMM (missing pattern) or `sequential_sum_product()` (todo).  The probabilistic model is
```py
process_noise = pyro.param(...)
sensor_noise = pyro.param(...)
bias_scale = pyro.param(...)

with plate("sensors", num_sensors):
    bias ~ MVN(0, bias_scale)
states = {}
states[-1] ~ MVN(0, init_state_cov)
for t in range(num_time_steps):
    states[t] ~ MVN(states[t - 1] @ ncv_dynamics, process_noise)
    with plate("sensors", num_sensors) as sensor_id:
        pyro.sample(MVN(states[t] @ obs_matrix + bias[sensor_id], sensor_noise)
                    obs=data[t])
```
you can run the experiments via `make sensor`.

~~i didn't include the plotting code which is in a notebook since it clutters the code.~~  @fritzo feel free to push directly to this branch. when this is ready to merge, i'd like to force-push squash the commits before merging.

issue.title: Add minimal failing tests for sensor fusion example
Implement affine funsor approximation
issue.body:
Addresses #72 
Blocking #245 (from which this PR was extracted)

This implements a general `extract_affine(-)` function that produces a canonical representation of any affine function, including constants, sums, einsums, indexing, reshaping and any other linear combination. The only requirement is that the function can be eagerly evaluated on `Tensor`s. I was surprised how general this turned out to be.

This required some fixes to `Einsum` to handle differently-batched inputs.

## Tested
- [x] unit test for `extract_affine()`
- [x] extra test for batched `Einsum`

issue.title: Add MultivariateNormal pattern for Binary to cover matmul
issue.body:
Unblocks #246 

This adds a pattern for `Binary` to the `MultivariateNormal` pattern matching code. Note this pattern is more complete but still unsound; soundness will be addressed by `.is_affine` #72

## Tested
- added a unit test
